answers.answer: Hi,At this time you do not have diabetes based on those fasting blood sugar values you reported. At most, what you have is borderline impaired fasting glucose, which CAN be a  prelude to diabetes in future.Is your thyroid disease autoimmune? (i.e did you have positive antibodies?). If you do have autoimmune thyroid disease, and along with that positive family history, I would suggest your doctor check an anti-GAD and anti-islet cell antibody, as well as c-peptide levels. Those antibodies mentioned are associated with Type 1 diabetes.Your gastroenterologist will be able to evaluate those liver tests and will likely also check for autoimmune liver disease.Hope this helps,Take care.
If all you are eating is veggies, fruit, and brown rice, where is your major source of complete proteins coming from?

question: Back in September my fasting glucose was 79, after that I had a wellness check in my company on 10/15, and I was suprised to see that my fasting glucose was 102.  So, I started checking my fasting blood sugars in the morning which range from 95 - 103 - usually about 100 or 101.  This scared me because my son has Type 1 diabetes (age 13), and my dad got type 1 at age 49.  I am age 50.  My dad's started out basically as type 1.  For the past four years, I have had slightly elevated liver enzymes - ALT 52 and GGT 106 - was my last test.  I also have Chloesterol at 224, with LDL at 154.  I have taken thyroid medication for the past 10 years for hypothyroid, and paxil for anti-anxiety.    Since 10/15 I have totally cut out all processed foods, and am eating a very restricted diet. (Veggies, Fruit, Brown Rice) I have lost about 10 pounds.  I am 5-7 and 1/2 inches and weigh 158.  I am also depressed right now, and have hot flashes throughout the day.  To top things off, I am going to physical therapy 2 times a week and a chiropractor 2 times a week because of a car accident the end of June as I have chronic back pain now.  I love to exercise, but I cannot jog anymore and it hurts to walk - so I ride the exercise bicycle.  The accident put a lot of added stress on my body.Anyway, I am wondering what I should do next?  I have an appointment with my gastroentrologist in two weeks (the soonest I could get in), but I wonder if I should be going somewhere else?  Do you think I have diabetes?  In the evening, I am usually 95.
title: What should I do next?
